Literature Review:
The silkworm, Bombyx mori, serves as a crucial model organism in life sciences and holds significant economic value in the sericulture industry. However, the Bombyx mori nucleopolyhedrovirus (BmNPV) poses a substantial threat, causing cocoon losses that account for over 60% of total losses from silkworm diseases (Xia et al., 2014). The absence of effective preventive or therapeutic measures against BmNPV has led researchers to focus on breeding disease-resistant silkworm varieties. This literature review explores the mechanisms of silkworm resistance to BmNPV and the advancements in antiviral breeding strategies.

The discovery of disease-resistant resources in 1989 marked the beginning of a concerted effort to identify resistance genes in silkworms (Lu et al., 2012). The advent of multi-omics technologies, including genomics, transcriptomics, and proteomics, has significantly advanced the identification and characterization of these genes. For instance, the use of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) has facilitated the localization of resistance genes, providing insights into the genetic basis of resistance (Yamamoto et al., 2018).

One of the primary mechanisms of resistance involves the interaction between the virus and host at the cellular level. Studies have shown that certain silkworm strains exhibit an innate immune response that limits viral replication. This response is mediated by pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) that detect viral components and activate downstream signaling pathways, leading to the production of antiviral proteins (Tanaka et al., 2016). Additionally, RNA interference (RNAi) has been identified as a crucial antiviral defense mechanism in silkworms. RNAi involves the degradation of viral RNA, thereby preventing the replication of the virus (Kolliopoulou et al., 2017).

Genetic modification has emerged as a promising approach to enhance silkworm resistance to BmNPV. The CRISPR/Cas9 system has been employed to edit genes associated with susceptibility to BmNPV, resulting in silkworms with enhanced resistance (Ma et al., 2019). Moreover, transgenic silkworms expressing antiviral proteins have been developed, demonstrating reduced viral loads and improved survival rates (Wang et al., 2015).

Hybrid breeding is another strategy that has been utilized to develop disease-resistant silkworm varieties. By crossing resistant and susceptible strains, researchers have been able to combine desirable traits and produce offspring with enhanced resistance to BmNPV (Zhang et al., 2013). This approach has been complemented by marker-assisted selection, which allows for the identification and selection of individuals carrying resistance alleles (Li et al., 2020).

The identification of candidate resistance genes has been a focal point of research. Several genes have been proposed to play a role in silkworm resistance to BmNPV, including those involved in the immune response, apoptosis, and cellular stress responses (Gong et al., 2018). For example, the gene encoding the protein BmNPV-resistant factor 1 (BmNRF1) has been shown to confer resistance by inhibiting viral replication (Liu et al., 2017).

Despite these advancements, challenges remain in fully elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying silkworm resistance to BmNPV. The complexity of virus-host interactions and the polygenic nature of resistance necessitate further research to identify additional resistance genes and understand their functional roles (Zhou et al., 2021). Moreover, the development of high-throughput screening methods and advanced bioinformatics tools will be essential in accelerating the discovery of novel resistance genes.

In conclusion, significant progress has been made in understanding the mechanisms of silkworm resistance to BmNPV and developing antiviral breeding strategies. The integration of multi-omics technologies, genetic modification, and hybrid breeding has led to the identification of candidate resistance genes and the development of disease-resistant silkworm varieties. Continued research in this field is crucial for clarifying the molecular mechanisms of resistance and promoting the sustainable production of silkworms in the sericulture industry.
